objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to introduce AutoMAT, a hierarchical and autonomous framework for alloy discovery that integrates large language models, automated CALPHAD-based simulations, and AI-driven search to accelerate alloy design.
objective.evidence: Here, we present AutoMAT, a hierarchical and autonomous framework grounded in and validated by experiments, which integrates large language models, automated CALPHAD-based simulations, and AI-driven search to accelerate alloy design.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the gap in alloy discovery methods that require trade-offs between speed, accuracy, generalizability, and cost, and the lack of a holistic solution that combines automation, data efficiency, physical fidelity, and scalability.
knowledge_gap.evidence: Computational methods have been developed to address this issue, but most still require trade-offs between speed, accuracy, generalizability, and cost. A holistic solution that combines automation, data efficiency, physical fidelity, and scalability remains elusive.

answer: AutoMAT is the first system to autonomously span the entire alloy design pipeline, from ideation and simulation to experimental validation.
The Simulation Layer fully and automatically integrates CALPHAD thermodynamic calculations into a closed-loop material discovery process for the first time.
The framework achieves high efficiency, accuracy, and interpretability without the need for manually curated large datasets.
evidence: To our knowledge, AutoMAT is the first system to autonomously span the entire alloy design pipeline, from ideation and simulation to experimental validation.

A cornerstone of our methodology is the Simulation Layer, which, for the first time, fully and automatically integrates CALPHAD thermodynamic calculations into a closed-loop material discovery process.
AutoMAT achieves high efficiency, accuracy, and interpretability without the need for manually curated large datasets.

inspirational_papers.evidence: Machine learning (ML)-based approaches can rapidly screen candidates, but often suffer from poor data efficiency, limited interpretability, and restricted generalization to new material systems9–11.

steps.step: Ideation Layer uses LLMs to propose candidate alloy systems based on user-defined property targets.
steps.input: User-defined property targets such as high yield strength, low density.
steps.output: Structured suggestions of candidate alloy systems.
steps.evidence: The Ideation Layer initiates the process by leveraging LLMs (e.g., ChatGPT and Claude) to propose candidate alloy systems aligned with user-defined property requirements.

steps.step: Simulation Layer refines candidates using CALPHAD-based thermodynamic modeling and AI-guided search.
steps.output: Refined alloy compositions with optimized properties.
steps.evidence: The Simulation Layer systematically refines the LLM-generated candidates through an AI-driven iterative neighborhood search.

steps.step: Validation Layer performs experimental synthesis and characterization of top-ranked candidates.
steps.input: Top-ranked candidate compositions from the Simulation Layer.
steps.evidence: The final Validation Layer performs experimental synthesis and characterization of top-ranked candidates.

tools.name: GPT-4o
tools.description: Used for natural language processing and knowledge extraction in the Ideation Layer.
tools.evidence: OpenAI's GPT-4o model (accessed via API) was utilized for all natural language processing and knowledge extraction tasks within the Ideation Layer.

tools.name: Thermo-Calc
tools.description: Used for thermodynamic calculations and properties predictions in the Simulation Layer.
tools.evidence: All thermodynamic calculations and properties predictions were conducted using Thermo-Calc software (version 2024b).

performance_summary.summary: AutoMAT identifies a titanium alloy with 8.1% lower density and comparable yield strength relative to the state-of-the-art reference, achieving the highest specific strength among all comparisons.
performance_summary.evidence: In a case study targeting a lightweight, high-strength alloy, AutoMAT identifies a titanium alloy with 8.1% lower density and comparable yield strength relative to the state-of-the-art reference, achieving the highest specific strength among all comparisons.

baselines.evidence: The target requirements included a yield strength approaching 850 MPa and a density below 4.36 g/cm3, with the goal of outperforming the state-of-the-art lightweight alloy Ti75.25Al20Cr4.75.

limitations.name: Limited Generalizability
limitations.description: The framework's performance is demonstrated on specific alloy systems, which may not generalize to all material types.
limitations.evidence: To demonstrate the effectiveness and generalizability of the AutoMAT framework, we present two case studies with distinct design goals.

future_directions.name: Expand to Other Material Classes
future_directions.description: The framework could be adapted to polymers, ceramics, and other material classes.
future_directions.evidence: With tailored prompt engineering, the Ideation Layer could rapidly generate candidate hypotheses for virtually any materials discovery challenge underpinned by a substantial literature base.

future_directions.name: Integrate More Simulation Techniques
future_directions.description: Incorporate other simulation methods like DFT or MD for different material properties.
future_directions.evidence: For different material classes or design targets, CALPHAD could be replaced with first-principles methods such as Density Functional Theory (DFT).
